author: Ewin Hannan
title: CFMEU stood down charged union organiser in 2012, commission hears
text:
Former CFMEU organiser Halafihi "Fihi" Kivalu has been charged with two counts of blackmail Jamila Toderas Share on twitter by Ewin Hannan Construction union officials told an employer in 2012 that they had stood down, and were investigating, a union organiser - despite the union's leadership insisting it only became aware of employee's alleged corruption this week.
In evidence to the Royal Commission into Trade Union Governance and Corruption on Friday, HD Projects director Clyde Daish said officials of the Construction, Forestry, Mining and Energy Union told him in 2012 they had stood down organiser Halafihi "Fihi' Kivalu.
Mr Daish said at the time he told the union, "we don't want to see Fihi on our sites, we've had trouble with him in the past".
"One of either Jason O'Mara or Anthony Vitler said words to the effect, "it's all right, he's been stood down. We're doing our own investigations of his conduct. He won't be coming to your sites,'; Mr Daish said.
Mr Kivalu was charged on Friday with two counts of blackmail and remains in custody until a bail hearing next Wednesday. He plead not guilty to the charges.
He was arrested on Thursday after it was revealed by the commission he allegedly extorted more than $150,000 from employers in the ACT.
Mr Kivalu has denied that the CFMEU knew he received payments from employers. And Mr Daish said the CFMEU officials at the meeting in 2012 did not tell him why they stood Mr Kivalu down.
Mr Daish said he agreed to pay $3,674 for 12 "ghost" CFMEU memberships in 2010 after Mr Kivalu and other CFMEU officials forced his employees to stop work on a project to build apartments.
 He said he employed six to eight workers on the site and almost all of them were already members of the union's NSW branch.
According to Mr Daish, Mr Kivalu said "you need to pay anyway ... I'll just make up 12 names, you need to pay for 12 employees,"
Describing the phantom workers as "ghosts", Mr Daish said his company had been under significant pressure to complete the project and "and this seemed like a fairly easy way to sort of move forward and get through it".
In a statement issued on Friday before Mr Daish's evidence was known, the CFMEU's national leadership said there had been no evidence from employers to the commission that the union was aware of the employer payments to Mr Kivalu.
"The leadership commends all the honest, hardworking officials and delegates who represent the union in their workplaces," they said. "We want them to know that we won't allow the good work they do and the reputation of the union to be tarnished and undone by corruption."
Employment MInister Eric Abetz said on Friday that it took "exposure in the royal commission and a police arrest for the CFMEU to finally admit to a problem of serious corruption within its ranks".
In evidence reminiscent of a Sopranos episode, the commission heard how Mr Kivalu met with employers in his car as well as restaurants and cafes in Canberra where they handed over envelopes of cash totalling tens of thousands of dollars. Mr Kivalu admitted receiving payments from two companies but insisted the money was given voluntarily.
Mr Kivalu was expelled this week by the CFMEU after contractor Elias Taleb told the commission he paid more than $135,000 to Mr Kivalu.
​​Mr Kivalu admitted that he took $60,000 from Mr Taleb. But asked by counsel assisting the commission Jeremy Stoljar whether he had also demanded $50,000 from Mr Taleb for the "Morris job", Mr Kivalu said: "I didn't demand any money from anyone."
